text: (upbeat music)
This course really exists
because whenever you move from on-premises to the cloud,
you have this big shift in the way
that you procure and consume resources.
So this course is really to help you wrap your mind
around exactly what changes
and then how can you handle those changes,
and what services exist
to help you see what you spend on AWS.
So this is about optimizing your costs
as much as it is about understanding them.
(upbeat music)
Week one of the course really starts at the beginning.
We first lay that foundation of like,
okay, what are we really talking about here?
Then we talk about the four pillars
of cloud financial management.
And then we use the AWS Pricing Calculator
to really show you how you can begin
to estimate your costs in the cloud.
(upbeat music)
Then starting in week two, we get more hands-on.
So we use things like AWS Cost Explorer,
we cover AWS Organizations for using multiple accounts,
and then we also cover AWS Budgets,
so that way you can get alerted
whenever costs are approaching certain thresholds.
And we cover AWS Config,
which allows you to evaluate
how you are tracking and tagging
your different AWS resources.
And then finally in week three,
we cover an example architecture,
and we go element by element,
and we cover various strategies for cost optimization.
And then we wrap it all up at the end
where we cover cost governance.
(upbeat music)
This course is intended for people
with a business or financial background
who do know a little bit about the cloud,
but you definitely don't have to be an expert.
That being said,
you don't necessarily need to be in business or finance
to find this course useful.
So we have the video content,
but there's also readings
where we expand more on what we did in the videos,
which include links to relevant tutorials,
where you can then go practice in your own account,
if you would like.
So that's something that I think
is super valuable about this course.
You have all this information
spread out across the internet,
and we are picking the pieces that us AWS experts think
are the most relevant,
and then we're putting it all in one place.
So I hope to see you in the course.
(upbeat music)
